choices.text: The head was engaged at the time of presentation
The cervicograph progress is satisfactory
The cervicograph status suggests that intervention is likely to be required
The cervicograph on repeat examination would touch the action line

questions.text: A G3P1A1 woman is admitted to the labor room at term with a cervix dilated to 4 cm, intact membranes, and the fetal head palpable at 3/5 per abdomen. After 4 hours, a repeat examination shows the cervix dilated to 5 cm with an unchanged station, and the cervicograph remains on the right side of the alert line. Which of the following statements about the progress of labor is correct? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The cervicograph status suggests that intervention is likely to be required

 

This question is based on the WHO modified partograph, the cervicograph status suggests that intervention is likely to be required. Active labor begins at 5 cm cervical dilatation. The patient progressed from 4 cm to only 5 cm in 4 hours, which is significantly slower than the expected rate. The cervicograph remaining on the right side of the alert line is an indication of slow progress. This slow progression, combined with the unchanged station of the fetal head, indicates that intervention may be necessary.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. The head was engaged at the time of presentation: This is incorrect because the head was palpable at 3/5 per abdomen. Engagement is defined when the head is palpable at 2/5 or less above the symphysis pubis. At 3/5, the head is considered "not engaged."

 

Option B. The cervicograph progress is satisfactory: The progress is not satisfactory as it has fallen to the right of the alert line, indicating slower than expected dilation.

 

Option D. The cervicograph on repeat examination would touch the action line: The action line is drawn four hours to the right of the alert line. Since the repeat examination was done at 4 hours and the cervicograph was only on the right side of the alert line (not specifically at the action line), this option is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

When labor progress falls to the right of the alert line on a partograph, it signals slow progress requiring careful assessment for potential intervention, as it indicates deviation from the expected normal labor pattern.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby is brought to OPD with jaundice and clay-colored stools. Lab work up reveals that the baby has conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. A liver biopsy was done and shows periductal proliferation. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Biliary atresia

 

An infant with jaundice, clay-coloured stools, and periductal proliferation on liver biopsy is highly suggestive of biliary atresia.

 

An infant with Biliary atresia presents with progressive jaundice, persistent yellow stools, and palpable liver with abnormal consistency.

 

Laboratory investigations show conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Ultrasonography reveals a triangular-cord sign (cone-shaped fibrotic mass cranial to the bifurcation of the portal vein).

 

HIDA test is more relevant for its negative predictive value (100%). Liver biopsy is diagnostic for biliary atresia. In biliary atresia, portal tract expansion, ductular proliferation and fibrosis is seen.

 

Laparotomy and perioperative cholangiography may be required in an infant with equivocal biopsy, findings and no excretion on HIDA scan, to evaluate for biliary atresia.

 

Biliary atresia is managed by Kasai procedure (hepato-portoenterostomy).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Crigler-Najjar syndrome: This is characterized by absent or deficient UGT enzyme leading to increased unconjugated bilirubin. It does not present with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia or clay-colored stools.

 

Option B. Rotor syndrome: A mild form of Dubin-Johnson syndrome that causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, but without the dark liver appearance seen in Dubin-Johnson syndrome. It does not present with periductal proliferation on liver biopsy.

 

Option C. Dubin-Johnson syndrome: Characterized by increased conjugated bilirubin and a dark liver appearance. It is an autosomal recessive disorder but does not present with the same liver biopsy findings as biliary atresia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An infant presenting with jaundice, clay-colored stools, and periductal proliferation on liver biopsy is highly suggestive of biliary atresia.

questions.text: Modified shock index is calculated using? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. HR/MAP

 

Modified shock index = HR/MAP

 

A shock index >0.9 is indicative of higher mortality.

 

HR: Heart rate

 

MAP: Mean arterial pressure

 

SBP: Systolic blood pressure

 

DBP: Diastolic blood pressure

 

# Commonly confused:

 

Formula for shock index= Heart rate/ systolic blood pressure

 

Educational Objective :

 

Modified shock index = HR/MAP

questions.text: A 25-year-old male who engaged in unprotected sexual intercourse develops urethral discharge one week later as shown in the given image below. What is the most likely causative organism for this condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neisseria gonorrhea

 

The given image shows purulent urethral discharge that developed one week after unprotected sexual intercourse is suggestive of acute urethritis. The most likely causative organism for acute urethritis in males is Neisseria gonorrhea.

 

Purulent urethral discharge can be seen in gonorrhea caused by Neisseria gonorrhea or lymphogranuloma venerum caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

 

Gonorrhea:

 

Gonorrhea is a disease acquired by sexual contact. The first step in infection is the infection of gonococci to the urethra or other mucosal surfaces. Pilli is involved in this adhesion. The cocci penetrate the intracellular spaces and reach subepithelial tissue by the third day of infection. The incubation period is 2-8 days. The major symptoms include urethral discharge and dysuria, usually without urinary frequency or urgency. The specific symptoms seen in males and females are as follows:

 

In males:

 

  • ﻿﻿The disease starts as acute urethritis. This infection may extend along the urethra to involve the prostate, seminal vesicles, and epididymis.
  • ﻿﻿Chronic urethritis may lead to stricture formation.
  • ﻿﻿The infection may spread to the periurethral tissues causing abscesses and multiple discharging sinuses (watercan perineum).

 

In females:

 

  • ﻿﻿The initial infection involves the cervix uteri and urethra which may extend to Bartholin glands, endometrium, and fallopian tubes.
  • ﻿﻿The vaginal mucosa is not usually affected in adults because the stratified squamous epithelium is resistant to infection by the cocci, and also because of the acidic pH of vaginal secretions.
  • ﻿﻿Pelvic inflammatory disease and salpingitis may lead to sterility.
  • ﻿﻿Rarely peritonitis may develop with perihepatic inflammation (Fitz Hugh Curtis syndrome)

 

Lab diagnosis:

 

The discharge is collected and subjected to Gram's stain which reveals gram-negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes. Stuart's transport medium is used. Cultures can be obtained from chocolate agar or Mueller-Hinton agar. Specifically, Thayer-Martin agar is used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

 

Treatment: Ceftriaxone (250mg, IM) single-dose + azithromycin 1 g PO, single-dose or doxycycline 100 mg PO BD for 7 days

 

The image below shows the Gram-stain of a urethral exudate showing typical intracellular gram-negative diplococci and pleomorphic extracellular gram-negative organisms

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Ureaplasma urealyticum is the second most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis next to chlamydia. That is why the initial etiological agent under suspicion always remains gonorrhea.

 

Option C. Herpes Simplex will be associated with vesicular lesions.

 

Option D. Trichomonas vaginalis generally presents with a frothy discharge

 

Educational Objective

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a significant cause of sexually transmitted infections, manifesting as acute urethritis with purulent discharge in males. Prompt diagnosis and treatment with appropriate antibiotics, such as a combination of ceftriaxone and azithromycin, are crucial to prevent complications and limit the spread of this highly contagious infection.

 

Non-gonococcal urethritis is caused by:

 

  • ﻿﻿Chlamydia trachomatis
  • ﻿﻿Ureaplasma urealyticum
  • ﻿﻿Mycoplasma genitalium
  • ﻿﻿Trichomonas vaginalis
  • ﻿﻿Herpes simplex virus (rare)
  • ﻿﻿Adenovirus
  • ﻿﻿Haemophilus vaginalis
  • ﻿﻿Mycoplasma genitalium

choices.text: It achieves maximum concentration in brain after IV infusion
Redistribution to adipose tissue and muscle is seen
The rapid decline in its effect is due to renal excretion

questions.text: Which of these statements is incorrect about Thiopentone? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The rapid decline in its effect is due to renal excretion

 

The rapid decline in thiopentone's effect is due to redistribution, not renal excretion. Thiopentone's ultra-short acting nature is due to:

 

  • Initial high concentration in brain due to high lipid solubility
  • Subsequent redistribution from brain to less perfused tissues like muscle and fat
  • This redistribution causes rapid decline in brain concentration leading to awakening
  • Continuous redistribution between highly perfused and less perfused lipid-soluble areas maintains this pattern
  • The process is independent of renal excretion

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. It is highly lipid soluble: Correct statement. This property allows rapid crossing of blood-brain barrier.

 

Option B. It achieves maximum concentration in brain after IV infusion: Correct statement. Due to brain being highly perfused and thiopentone's lipid solubility.

 

Option C. Redistribution to adipose tissue and muscle is seen: Correct statement. This is the key mechanism for its short duration of action.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The rapid decline in thiopentone's anesthetic effect is due to redistribution to less perfused tissues, not renal excretion, explaining its ultra-short acting nature.

 

THIOPENTONE

 

  • T - Thiobarbiturates
  • H - Hyperthyroidism
  • I - Inadvertent intra-arterial Injection causes vasospasm (treatment - flush with NS, heparin, lignocaine)
  • O - pH 10.5 (alkaline)
  • P - pH
  • Porphyrias (C/I)
  • Prolongation of QT interval
  • E - Epilepsy
  • N - Neuroanesthesia (DOC)
  • T - Termination of action - redistribution

questions.text: Which enzyme is responsible for removal of Triglycerides from chylomicron? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lipoprotein lipase

 

Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) is present on the endothelium of blood vessels and is responsible for breaking down triglycerides in chylomicrons and VLDL into fatty acids. When chylomicrons travel via blood vessels, LPL acts on them to release fatty acids which can then be taken up by tissues. This enzyme is activated by Apo C-II (which acts as a cofactor) and insulin. LPL is considered an anabolic enzyme since it helps store fats in tissues during the fed state.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amylase: This is incorrect because amylase is involved in carbohydrate metabolism, specifically the breakdown of starch. It has no role in triglyceride metabolism.

 

Option C. Hormone sensitive lipase: This is incorrect because HSL is present in adipose tissue and breaks down stored triglycerides during fasting/starvation. It is activated by glucagon and inhibited by insulin, unlike LPL which shows opposite regulation.

 

  • Insulin activate (love) Lipoprotein lipase
  • Insulin inhibit (hate) Hormone sensitive lipase

 

Option D. LCAT (Lecithin-cholesterol acyltransferase): This is incorrect because LCAT is involved in cholesterol metabolism, specifically the esterification of cholesterol in HDL particles. It has no direct role in triglyceride metabolism from chylomicrons.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Lipoprotein lipase is the key enzyme responsible for hydrolyzing triglycerides from circulating chylomicrons and VLDL at the endothelial surface, facilitating fatty acid uptake by tissues.

questions.text: Which of the following non-invasive investigations provides the most accurate prognostic information with respect to predicting risks of perioperative cardiac complications? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dobutamine stress echocardiography

 

  • This is an echocardiogram that is performed while the heart is under the stress of increased workload. If a patient cannot exercise, a drug called dobutamine is administered to simulate the effects of exercise on the heart.
  • The test helps identify areas of the heart that may not be receiving enough blood due to blockages in the coronary arteries. A significant change in the motion of the heart wall during the test is a strong predictor of perioperative cardiac complications, making this test highly valuable in the mentioned context.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exercise ECG testing: Exercise ECG testing, also known as exercise stress testing or treadmill testing, involves the patient exercising on a treadmill or stationary bicycle while their heart rate, blood pressure, and electrocardiogram (ECG) are monitored. The purpose is to determine how the heart responds to the stress of exercise. Abnormal changes in the ECG during or after exercise may suggest coronary artery disease (CAD). While this test can indicate the presence of CAD, it does not specifically predict perioperative cardiac complications.

 

Option C. Myocardial perfusion scintigraphy: Also known as a nuclear stress test, this investigation involves injecting a small amount of radioactive substance into the patient and using a special camera to visualize how blood flows through the heart muscle, both at rest and during stress (either exercise or with a medication). This test can identify areas of the heart that aren't getting enough blood, indicative of CAD. While it can detect and evaluate the severity of CAD, it's less specific than dobutamine stress echocardiography in predicting perioperative cardiac complications.

 

Option D. Coronary angiography: This is a procedure in which a contrast dye is injected into the coronary arteries, and X-rays are taken to visualize the flow of blood through these arteries. It is used to directly visualize blockages in the coronary arteries. As the "gold standard" for diagnosing CAD, coronary angiography can provide detailed information about the location and severity of blockages. However, it's an invasive procedure, involving threading a catheter through the blood vessels to the heart, and carries risks such as bleeding, allergic reactions, or kidney damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dobutamine stress echocardiography is the most accurate non-invasive investigation for predicting perioperative cardiac complications due to its ability to simulate exercise and identify areas of the heart with reduced blood flow.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 935

questions.text: What is the most important assessment based on the treatment given to the patient and their clinical management in a health care facility? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Process

 

Evaluation of "process" can assess a health care facility based on the treatment given to the patient and their clinical management.

 

The process of evaluation involves several steps, such as

 

  • Determining what needs to be evaluated
  • Establishing standards and criteria
  • Planning the methodology
  • Gathering information
  • Analyzing the results
  • Taking action
  • Re-evaluating

 

There are three types of evaluation: structure evaluation, process evaluation, and outcome evaluation.

 

  1. Evaluation of "structure": This is evaluation of whether facilities, equipment, manpower and organization meet a standard accepted by experts as good.
  2. Evaluation of "process": The process of medical care includes the problems of recognition, diagnostic procedures, treatment and clinical management, care and prevention. The way in which the various activities of the programme is carried out is evaluated by comparing with a predetermined standard. An objective and systematic way of evaluating the physician (or nurse) performance is known as "Medical (or nursing) Audit"
  3. Evaluation of "outcome": This is concerned with the end results, that is, whether persons using health services experience measurable benefits such as improved survival or reduced disability. The traditional outcome components are the "5 Ds" of ill-health, viz. disease, discomfort, dissatisfaction, disability and death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Outcome: Focuses on the end results of healthcare, such as improved health status and reduced disease and disability.

 

  • Not Correct: It measures the results of care, not the processes used to deliver it.

 

Option C. Structure: Examines the physical and organizational infrastructure, like facilities, equipment, and staffing.

 

  • Not Correct: It evaluates resources and infrastructure, not the actual delivery of care.

 

Option D. Input: Assesses resources required for healthcare, such as funding, manpower, and materials.

 

  • Not Correct: It looks at the resources used, not how care is delivered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "process" evaluation is the most relevant assessment for determining the quality of treatment and clinical management provided to patients in a healthcare facility. It focuses on the procedures and methods used in patient care, ensuring adherence to established standards and guidelines.

questions.text: A medical student presented with complaints of repeated episodes lasting approximately 30 minutes, characterized by breathlessness, palpitations, sweating, hyperventilation, and a fear of an impending heart attack. The patient has experienced these episodes 5-6 times per month over the last 6 months, and investigations did not reveal any obvious abnormalities. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Panic Disorder

 

The clinical presentation of a medical student with repeated episodes of breathlessness, palpitations, sweating, hyperventilation, and fear of an impending heart attack, each lasting approximately 30 minutes and occurring 5-6 times per month over the last 6 months, with no abnormalities found in investigations, is highly suggestive of Panic Disorder. Panic Disorder is characterized by recurrent, unexpected panic attacks, which are abrupt surges of intense fear or discomfort reaching a peak within minutes. The symptoms described, including palpitations, sweating, and hyperventilation, are common during panic attacks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD): GAD is characterized by persistent and excessive worry about various things, but it does not typically involve the acute, intense episodes of fear or the physical symptoms of a panic attack.

 

Option C. Depression: While depression can have anxiety symptoms and panic attacks, the primary feature is a persistent low mood and loss of interest or pleasure in activities, which is not mentioned in this scenario.

 

Option D. Social Phobia: Also known as social anxiety disorder, this involves a significant fear of social or performance situations. The symptoms described do not specifically relate to social or performance situations, making this diagnosis less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Panic disorder is characterized by recurrent and unexpected panic attacks with anticipatory anxiety. Patients may start ‘avoiding’ situations that they link with the panic attack. Treatment includes a combination of pharmacotherapy [benzodiazepines for short term and SSRIs for long term] and psychotherapy [CBT, relaxation techniques] is preferred.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 402.

questions.text: In which of the following devices is Murphy's eye seen? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Endotracheal tube

 

Murphy's eye is a characteristic feature seen in many endotracheal tubes:

 

 

  • Murphy's eye is a hole located on the side of the distal end of an endotracheal tube. It acts as a safety feature.
  • The primary purpose of Murphy's eye is to provide an alternate route for ventilation in case the main lumen of the tube becomes obstructed, either by being pressed against the tracheal wall or by accumulated secretions or blood.
  • In addition to ensuring continued ventilation, Murphy's eye also reduces the risk of trauma to the tracheal mucosa by reducing suction against the tracheal wall when the main tip is occluded.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasopharyngeal airway: This device does not have a Murphy's eye. It is a simple tube inserted into the nasal passage to maintain an open airway.

 

Option B. Laryngoscope: This is a tool used for visualizing the larynx during intubation and does not have a Murphy's eye.

 

Option C. Bronchoscope: This is an instrument used for visualizing the inside of the airways and does not have a Murphy's eye.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Murphy's eye is an important safety feature found in endotracheal tubes, providing an alternative pathway for ventilation and reducing the risk of mucosal trauma.

choices.text: Stop the blood transfusion and push normal saline
Continue the blood transfusion and perform an ECG
Investigate for clerical errors in the blood transfusion process
Administer corticosteroids and monitor vital signs

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a known history of thalassemia undergoes blood transfusion. Following the transfusion, she developed symptoms of anxiety, hypotension, and fever. What is the next appropriate step in the management of this patient? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stop the blood transfusion and push normal saline

 

The patient's symptoms of anxiety, hypotension, and fever after a blood transfusion suggest a possible transfusion reaction, which could be due to an ABO blood group incompatibility. In such cases, the immediate and appropriate step is to stop the blood transfusion immediately to prevent further complications. Pushing normal saline helps to dilute the mismatched blood and flush out the incompatible components from the patient's circulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Continuing the blood transfusion in the presence of these symptoms would be inappropriate and potentially harmful, as it could exacerbate the transfusion reaction.

 

Option C. While investigating for clerical errors in the blood transfusion process is important, it should be done after stopping the transfusion and stabilizing the patient's condition.

 

Option D. Administering corticosteroids may be helpful in managing severe transfusion reactions, but stopping the transfusion and pushing normal saline are the immediate and crucial steps to be taken.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the event of suspected transfusion reactions, characterized by symptoms like anxiety, hypotension, and fever, the immediate action should be to stop the blood transfusion and push normal saline to prevent further complications.

choices.text: May be seen in Intrauterine Pregnancy
May be seen in Ectopic Pregnancy

questions.text: All of the following statements about Arias-Stella Reaction are true, except: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Follicular Endometrium

 

The Arias-Stella reaction is characterized by hypersecretory changes in the endometrial glands in response to high levels of chorionic gonadotropin. It shows nuclear enlargement, hyperchromasia, and cytoplasmic vacuolization of the endometrial glandular cells. This reaction represents a hypersecretory endometrium, not a follicular (proliferative) endometrium. The reaction is observed in both intrauterine and ectopic pregnancies as it is a hormonal response to hCG regardless of implantation site.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. May be seen in Intrauterine Pregnancy: This is a true statement. Arias-Stella reaction is commonly observed in intrauterine pregnancies as the endometrium responds to the high levels of hCG produced by the developing trophoblast.

 

Option B. May be seen in Ectopic Pregnancy: This is a true statement. Even when implantation occurs outside the uterus (ectopic pregnancy), the circulating hCG can still stimulate the endometrial glands to undergo the Arias-Stella reaction.

 

Option C. Hyper-secretory Endometrium: This is a true statement. The Arias-Stella reaction is characterized by hypersecretory changes in the endometrial glands, with distinctive nuclear and cytoplasmic alterations that differ from typical secretory changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Arias-Stella reaction represents a hypersecretory endometrial change in response to hCG that can occur in both intrauterine and ectopic pregnancies, but it is not associated with follicular (proliferative) endometrial patterns which are estrogen-dependent rather than progesterone/hCG-dependent.

questions.text: Total number of children born to a woman in comparison with other women of same reproductive age is called:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) TFR (Total Fertility Rate)

 

Explanation:

 

The total number of children born to a woman in comparison with other women of the same reproductive age group is referred to as the Total Fertility Rate (TFR).

 

The following definitions are provided:

 

  • TFR: Total number of children born to a woman
  • GRR: Number of girls born to a woman in her entire reproductive lifespan
  • NRR: Total number of girls born to a woman in her entire reproductive lifespan, minus mortality (taking into account their deaths)
  • GFR: Number of live births per 1,000 women in the reproductive age group

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. NRR (Net Reproduction Rate) - This option is incorrect because NRR takes into account the mortality of the girls born, not the total number of children born to a woman.

 

Option C. GFR (General Fertility Rate) - This option is incorrect because GFR is the number of live births per 1,000 women in the reproductive age group, not the total number of children born to an individual woman.

 

Option D. GRR (Gross Reproduction Rate) - This option is incorrect because GRR specifically refers to the number of girls born to a woman, not the total number of children born.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Total Fertility Rate (TFR) is the measure that represents the total number of children born to a woman in comparison with other women of the same reproductive age group.

choices.text: Cannot be differentiated serologically from T. pallidum

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Yaws is not true? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Spread by sexual transmission

 

Explanation:

 

Yaws is not spread by sexual transmission. It is a non-venereal treponematosis caused by Treponema pertenue that spreads through direct contact with infected skin lesions. The disease primarily affects children in tropical regions, with transmission occurring through skin-to-skin contact during play or other close physical contact. Unlike syphilis, which is sexually transmitted, yaws spreads through non-sexual contact primarily in rural communities with poor hygiene.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Caused by T. pertenue - This statement is true. Yaws is indeed caused by Treponema pertenue, which is a non-venereal Treponema species closely related to T. pallidum (the causative agent of syphilis). The spirochete morphologically resembles T. pallidum but has different transmission patterns and epidemiology.

 

Option C. Has cross immunity with syphilis - This statement is true. Yaws provides cross immunity with syphilis because both organisms share common antigens. This cross-immunity has epidemiological significance, as regions with high prevalence of yaws typically have lower rates of syphilis.

 

Option D. Cannot be differentiated serologically from T. pallidum - This statement is true. Standard serological tests cannot differentiate between antibodies produced in response to T. pallidum and those produced in response to T. pertenue infection. Both infections produce positive results in non-treponemal tests (VDRL, RPR) and treponemal tests (FTA-ABS, TPHA).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Yaws is a non-venereal treponematosis caused by T. pertenue that spreads through direct skin contact, primarily affecting children in tropical regions, and while it shares many features with syphilis including cross-immunity and serological similarities, it differs fundamentally in its mode of transmission.

questions.text: A photographer who recently returned from Africa presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, and hemorrhagic manifestations. He died despite treatment, and an autopsy revealed intranuclear Torres bodies in the liver. Which of the following vaccines could have prevented it? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 17D

 

The above clinical vignette is suggestive of yellow fever and the use of 17D vaccine could have prevented this.

 

17D vaccine is a live-attenuated vaccine administered through the subcutaneous route. It is contraindicated in infants less than 9 months of age, in pregnancy, and in individuals with egg allergy.

 

Yellow fever is caused by flavivirus and is endemic to certain parts of Africa and America. It occurs in two patterns: the urban cycle and the sylvatic cycle. Aedes aegypti is the vector in the urban cycle, while Aedes africanus is responsible for transmission in the sylvatic cycle.

 

Patients present with acute onset fever, headache, and vomiting. Jaundice and hemorrhagic manifestations can also be present. Ultimately, hepatic or renal failure can result in death.

 

Torres bodies are intranuclear eosinophilic inclusion bodies in hepatocytes. These are rarely seen in yellow fever. To prevent the establishment of the disease in India, strict vaccination and quarantine protocols for travelers from endemic areas are enforced.

 

Other options:

 

Option B: Nakayama vaccine is used for immunization against Japanese encephalitis. Culex tritaeniorhynchus is the principal vector. There is a sudden onset of fever and vomiting, which later progresses to encephalitis. In India, it was first reported in Vellore and continues to be active in the country.

 

Option C. Weigl's vaccine is the earliest used vaccine against epidemic typhus caused by Rickettsia prowazekii. The main foci of the disease are Europe, Africa, South America, and Asia. Kashmir is the endemic spot in India. Pediculus humans corporis (human body louse) is the vector. Symptoms include fever and chills. A characteristic rash on the trunk and limbs, sparing the face, palms, and soles, may also be seen.

 

Option D. Jeryl-Lynn strain of the mumps virus is used against the disease as a live-attenuated vaccine. It is contraindicated in pregnancy and individuals allergic to eggs. Mumps present as parotid swelling associated with fever and tenderness.

 

Educational Objective

 

The 17D vaccine could have prevented the yellow fever that led to the photographer's severe symptoms and death. This highlights the importance of appropriate vaccination before traveling to areas where yellow fever is endemic.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of the nervous system, which of the following nerves can be tested by touching the highlighted structure? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. IX

 

The structure marked is uvula. The sensory supply to the uvula is by the glossopharyngeal nerve and it is tested in this case.

 

Motor supply to the Uvula is by vagus nerve and sensory supply by Glossopharyngeal nerve.

 

Since touch is sensory activity hence the answer is sensory nerve CN IX in this case.

 

If the movement is stressed in question then motor nerve (CN X) will be the answer

 

Cranial Nerve IX (Glossopharyngeal Nerve) innervates -

 

Sensory: Supplies sensation to the posterior one-third of the tongue, oropharynx, and part of the ear canal. It also has a role in taste for the posterior third of the tongue.

 

Motor: Supplies the stylopharyngeus muscle.

 

Parasympathetic: Involved in salivation via the parotid gland.

 

Clinical Examination: Sensation of the posterior one-third of the tongue can be tested using a cotton swab. The gag reflex can also be used to test the glossopharyngeal nerve where the gag reflex is triggered by touching the back of the throat or as the nerve innervates the uvula, touching it could also elicit a response, verifying the integrity of the nerve.

 

Pharyngeal plexus:

 

The nerve supply to the pharynx is primarily provided by the pharyngeal plexus. The pharyngeal branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve and the vagus nerve combine to form it. It also receives input from the superior cervical ganglion. The motor supply is provided by the vagus nerve, and the sensory supply is provided by the glossopharyngeal nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cranial Nerve X (Vagus Nerve): It gives innervations

 

  • Sensory: Provides sensation to parts of the ear canal and the pharynx. It also has visceral sensory functions for the heart, lungs, and abdominal organs.
  • Motor: Supplies muscles of the larynx, pharynx, and soft palate. It's also responsible for the "cough reflex."
  • Parasympathetic: Supplies the heart, lungs, and digestive tract up to the splenic flexure of the colon.
    • Clinical Examination: The gag reflex is a common method to test the vagus nerve (motor component) since it's responsible for the upward movement of the palate or Examining the uvula when saying "ahh" to see if it deviates (it should stay midline).

 

Option C. Cranial Nerve XI (Accessory Nerve): Supplies the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.

 

  • Clinical Examination: Patients are asked to turn their head against resistance to test the sternocleidomastoid or Patients are asked to shrug their shoulders against resistance to test the trapezius.

 

Option D. Cranial Nerve XII (Hypoglossal Nerve): Supplies the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue.

 

  • Clinical Examination: The patient is asked to protrude their tongue. If the nerve is damaged, the tongue will deviate to the side of the lesion.

questions.text: Calculate Maternal Mortality Ratio in a population of 2 lacs, with 4000 live births, Death were 4 by PPH, 2 deaths by electrocution, 2 deaths by sepsis, 2 deaths by abortion, 2 deaths due to ectopic pregnancy, and 5 still births. (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 250 per 1 lac

 

Explanation:

 

The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is calculated by dividing the number of maternal deaths by the number of live births and multiplying by 100,000.

 

Maternal death is defined as the death of a mother at any time during pregnancy, labor, delivery, or within 42 days of delivery, provided it is related to maternity or its complications.

 

In the given scenario, the maternal deaths are:

 

  • 4 deaths by postpartum hemorrhage (PPH)
  • 2 deaths by sepsis
  • 2 deaths by abortion
  • 2 deaths due to ectopic pregnancy

 

These deaths should be included in the calculation as they are related to maternity or its complications.

 

The deaths due to electrocution and stillbirths are not included in the calculation of MMR.

 

Therefore, the total number of maternal deaths is 10 (4 + 2 + 2 + 2).

 

The number of live births is given as 4,000.

 

MMR = (Number of maternal deaths / Number of live births) × 100,000

 

= (10 / 4,000) × 100,000

 

= 250 per 1,00,000 live births

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is calculated by dividing the number of maternal deaths (deaths related to maternity or its complications) by the number of live births and multiplying by 100,000.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman from Nagaland presents with right-sided hearing loss and tinnitus. On examination, there is a dull tympanic membrane, and lymph nodes in the posterior triangle of the neck are palpable. She is from a region endemic for nasopharyngeal carcinoma. What is the most appropriate management for this condition?  (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radiotherapy (RT)

 

Explanation: 


Radiotherapy is the most appropriate management because:

 

  • The presentation suggests nasopharyngeal carcinoma with: 
    • Unilateral hearing loss due to serous otitis media (dull tympanic membrane)
    • Painless cervical lymphadenopathy
    • Patient from endemic region (Nagaland)
  • Nasopharyngeal carcinomas are highly radiosensitive tumors
  • This is the first-line treatment for nasopharyngeal carcinoma
  • Radiotherapy provides better outcomes compared to surgery due to: 
    • Difficult surgical access to nasopharynx
    • High risk of complications with surgery
    • Rich lymphatic drainage of the area

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Radical neck dissection

 

  • Only addresses lymph node metastases
  • Doesn't treat the primary tumor
  • Not first-line treatment without prior radiotherapy

 

Option B. Grommet insertion with steroids

 

  • Only treats the secondary middle ear effusion
  • Doesn't address the underlying malignancy
  • Can be considered as supportive treatment for hearing loss

 

Option D. Wait and watch

 

  • Inappropriate for suspected malignancy
  • Delays definitive treatment
  • Can lead to disease progression

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Radiotherapy is the primary treatment modality for nasopharyngeal carcinoma due to the tumor's high radiosensitivity and anatomical considerations.

 

Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma

choices.text: 1000 for mother and 400 for ASHA
1400 for mother and 600 for ASHA
600 for mother and 400 for ASHA
400 for mother and 600 for ASHA

questions.text: In an urban area in the state of Madhya Pradesh, a first-time pregnant woman visits a healthcare facility for her delivery following encouragement from an ASHA worker. What monetary advantages will they obtain under the Janani Suraksha Yojana? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 1000 for mother and 400 for ASHA

 

Under the Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY), a cash incentive scheme, pregnant women who deliver in healthcare facilities are provided financial assistance. The scheme aims to reduce maternal and neonatal mortality by promoting institutional delivery among poor pregnant women.

 

Madhya Pradesh is categorized as a Low Performing State (LPS), the incentives are as follows:

 

  • Mother's Package: ₹1000
  • ASHA's Package: ₹400

 

Educational Objective:  

 

 

(LPS: Low performing states; HPS: High performing states)

 

(LPS include UP, Uttarakhand, MP, Jharkhand, Bihar, Chhattisgarh, Odisha, Assam, Jammu & Kashmir, Rajasthan)

choices.text: Child is delivered after death of biological father
Child is born to an unmarried couple
Child is abandoned by the parents

questions.text: A posthumous child can be best defined as: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Child is delivered after death of biological father

 

  • A posthumous child is defined as a child who is born after the death of one of their biological parents, typically the father. This term is most commonly used to describe children whose fathers passed away before they were born.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Delivery of a macerated fetus: A macerated fetus refers to a fetus that has died in utero and has undergone specific changes due to prolonged retention in the uterus.

 

Option C. Child is born to an unmarried couple: This describes the marital status of the parents and does not pertain to the death of a parent.

 

Option D. Child is abandoned by the parents: This refers to a situation where a child is left without care by their parents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A posthumous child is one who is born after the death of one of their biological parents, most commonly the father.

questions.text: Among the following options, which one is considered a presumptive sign of early pregnancy? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Softening of the cervix

 

Softening of the cervix or Goodell’s sign is a sign that appears at around 6 weeks in early pregnancy. It is an early pregnancy sign. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ballottement: This is a 2nd trimester sign of pregnancy. Ballottement can be external or internal. 

 

Option B. Braxton Hicks contractions: These are painless, irregular uterine contractions that begin in the second trimester. They are symptoms of the patient and not signs. 

 

Option C. Amenorrhoea: Amenorrhoea in a patient who has been having previously regular cycles is the most common symptom of pregnancy. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Softening of the cervix or Goodell’s sign is a Presumptive sign of the 1st trimester of pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following is a water soluble contrast? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Iohexol

 

Explanation:

 

lohexol is a non-ionic, water-soluble iodinated contrast medium, used in various radiographic studies including CT scans, angiography, and myelography. It is known for its low osmolality and good safety profile, making it suitable for intravascular use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Barium: While barium sulfate is a contrast agent, it is not water-soluble and is primarily used for gastrointestinal studies.

 

Option C. Bromium: Not typically used as a contrast agent in medical imaging.

 

Option D. Calcium: Not used as a contrast agent. In medical imaging, calcium deposits may be identified by their radiographic appearance, but calcium itself is not administered as a contrast medium.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Ito cells
Endothelial cells

questions.text: Which part of the liver stores vitamin A?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ito cells

 

Explanation

 

  • Ito cells are the cells that store vitamin A in the liver. These cells, also known as hepatic stellate cells, are located in the space of Disse, which is between the hepatocytes and the endothelial cells in the liver.
  • Ito cells play a role in liver function and pathology, and are involved in the regulation of extracellular matrix synthesis and degradation, as well as in the response to liver injury. They are also responsible for the storage and release of vitamin A in the liver.
  • Kupffer cells, also known as stellate macrophages and Kupffer-Borowicz cells; are specialized macrophages located in the liver that form part of the mononuclear phagocyte system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hepatocytes: Incorrect, while hepatocytes are the main functional cells of the liver and perform numerous metabolic, synthetic, and detoxifying functions, they are not the primary storage sites for vitamin A.

 

Option C. Endothelial cells: Incorrect, these cells line the blood vessels of the liver and are involved in filtration and blood flow regulation within the organ, not in vitamin storage.

 

Option D. Kupffer cells: Incorrect, Kupffer cells are the liver's resident macrophages, involved in immune responses and the breakdown of red blood cells, not in storing vitamins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ito cells (hepatic stellate cells) are the primary storage sites for vitamin A in the liver. Their role extends beyond vitamin storage to include critical functions in the regulation of the extracellular matrix and the liver's response to injury.

questions.text: A young woman presents with prolapse. A sacrohysteropexy is being done. A mesh is being placed. Where is this mesh fixed to? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sacral promontory

 

In cases of pelvic organ prolapse, surgical procedures like sacrocolpopexy or sacrohysteropexy are performed to provide support to the prolapsed organs using a mesh.

 

  • In sacrocolpopexy, the mesh is typically fixed from the vaginal vault (in patients who have undergone a hysterectomy) to the sacral promontory.
  • In sacrohysteropexy, the mesh is fixed from the cervix to the sacral promontory, providing support to the uterus in younger patients who still have their uterus intact.

 

The sacral promontory, which is the uppermost part of the sacrum, serves as a strong and reliable point for attachment, providing the necessary support to the pelvic structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ischial spine: The ischial spine is a point of attachment for pelvic muscles and ligaments, but it is not used for mesh fixation in sacrocolpopexy or sacrohysteropexy.

 

Option B. Ischial tuberosity: This structure serves as an attachment site for muscles and ligaments of the pelvis, but it is not involved in sacrocolpopexy procedures.

 

Option D. Pubic symphysis: This is a cartilaginous joint connecting the left and right pubic bones. It is not utilized as a fixation point in sacrocolpopexy or sacrohysteropexy surgeries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In sacrocolpopexy and sacrohysteropexy procedures for pelvic organ prolapse, the mesh is fixed to the sacral promontory, providing strong support to the prolapsed organs.

questions.text: A 1-week-old child was presented with early cataract. He also has refusal to feed, vomiting, lethargy, jaundice, and sepsis. This can be caused due to the deficiency of which enzyme? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase

 

The clinical presentation described in the question is characteristic of classic galactosemia, a metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALT). This enzyme deficiency leads to an accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate, which causes toxicity, especially in the liver, kidney, and lens of the eye.

 

The symptoms presented in the question are early cataract, refusal to feed, vomiting, lethargy, jaundice, and sepsis—are typical of galactosemia. The cataract seen in these patients is often described as an "," which is due to the accumulation of galactitol in the lens, a metabolite of galactose.

 

 

Galactosemia can be of three types:

 

  • Type 1: Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase deficiency (most common and severe form).
  • Type 2: Galactokinase deficiency.
  • Type 3: UDP-galactose-4-epimerase deficiency.

 

Among these, Type 1 galactosemia (GALT deficiency) is responsible for the symptoms described and is the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Catalase: Catalase is an enzyme involved in the breakdown of hydrogen peroxide to water and oxygen. It is not associated with galactose metabolism or the symptoms described, making this an incorrect choice.

 

Option C. Aldose reductase: Aldose reductase converts galactose to galactitol in the lens, contributing to cataract formation in patients with galactosemia. However, the enzyme's deficiency is not the primary cause of the described condition; instead, its action exacerbates the effects of galactosemia.

 

Option D. Hexokinase: Hexokinase is involved in the phosphorylation of glucose, not galactose. It plays no direct role in the pathogenesis of galactosemia or the symptoms mentioned in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classic galactosemia is caused by a deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase and presents with early cataracts, feeding difficulties, vomiting, lethargy, jaundice, and sepsis in newborns.

questions.text: What blood group should be given to a patient with Bombay blood group? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oh

 

The Bombay blood group, also known as the Oh phenotype, is one of the rarest blood groups in the world. It was discovered in 1952 by Dr Y.M. Bhende.

 

Individuals with this blood group lack the H antigen, which is a precursor to the A and B antigens found on the red blood cells of most individuals. The absence of the H antigen means that even blood type O, which normally has the H antigen, is not compatible with individuals who have the Bombay phenotype.

 

People with the Bombay blood group produce anti-H antibodies in addition to anti-A and anti-B antibodies. This means that they cannot receive blood from any of the common blood types (A, B, AB, or O), as all of these contain the H antigen and would lead to a severe transfusion reaction.

 

The only blood that can be safely transfused into a person with the Bombay blood group is blood from another Bombay blood group donor, which is denoted as Oh.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AB: Individuals with blood group AB have both A and B antigens. This blood group would not be compatible with a Bombay blood group recipient, as it would cause a severe transfusion reaction due to the presence of H antigen.

 

Option B. O positive: Blood group O positive still has the H antigen, even though it lacks A and B antigens. Transfusing O positive blood into a Bombay blood group individual would also lead to a transfusion reaction.

 

Option D. O negative: Like O positive, O negative blood has the H antigen and would not be suitable for a Bombay blood group recipient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bombay blood group (Oh phenotype) is extremely rare, and individuals with this blood type can only receive blood from another Bombay blood group donor due to the absence of the H antigen and the presence of anti-H antibodies.

questions.text: Most common cancer in Indian women? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Breast cancer

 

Breast cancer is currently the most common cancer among Indian women. This trend has shifted over the past decade. Previously, cervical cancer was the most prevalent, but recent data indicate that breast cancer has surpassed cervical cancer in incidence. The increased awareness, better screening programs, and lifestyle changes are contributing factors to this shift. Breast cancer is now the leading cancer affecting women in India, followed by cervical cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical cancer: While it used to be the most common cancer in Indian women, it is now the second most common after breast cancer.

 

Option B. Endometrial cancer: This is less common compared to breast and cervical cancers in Indian women.

 

Option D. Ovarian cancer: Ovarian cancer has a lower incidence rate compared to breast and cervical cancers among Indian women.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Breast cancer is the most common cancer among Indian women, having overtaken cervical cancer in recent years.

choices.text: It is faster than AV nodal pathway
It is slower than AV nodal pathway

questions.text: Identify the false statement about the bundle of Kent? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. It is slower than AV nodal pathway

 

The false statement about the bundle of Kent is that it is slower than the AV nodal pathway. In fact, the bundle of Kent provides a rapid conduction pathway between the atrium and the ventricle, bypassing the AV node. This pathway allows for faster conduction than the AV nodal pathway due to the nature of the myocardial fibers involved and the lack of delay that normally occurs at the AV node.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is faster than the AV nodal pathway: This statement is actually true. The bundle of Kent facilitates faster electrical conduction from the atria to the ventricles by bypassing the slower AV node, contributing to the clinical manifestations of pre-excitation syndromes.

 

Option C. Leads to a short PR interval: This is true. The rapid conduction via the bundle of Kent results in premature activation of the ventricles, reflected as a shortened PR interval on an electrocardiogram.

 

Option D. Leads to a prolonged QRS duration: This is also true. The activation of ventricular myocardium via the accessory pathway occurs in a less synchronized manner compared to normal conduction through the His-Purkinje system, leading to a broader and prolonged QRS complex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bundle of Kent is an accessory pathway connecting atrium and ventricle with conduction through Na+ channels leading to bypass of physiological AV conduction.

 

Reference - Harrison/Cardiology/WPW

questions.text: A 5-year-old child who is eagerly drinking water and skin pinch goes back slowly. Which category does the child belong according to IMNCI? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Yellow

 

The Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness (IMNCI) is a strategy developed by the World Health Organization (WHO) and UNICEF to improve child health in developing countries. The child's symptoms of eagerly drinking water and a slow skin pinch return are indicative of some dehydration, which falls under the yellow category in the IMNCI guidelines.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Green: The green category denotes "no dehydration." This would be for a child who shows no signs of dehydration and is otherwise healthy.

 

Option C. Pink: The pink category denotes "severe dehydration." Signs of severe dehydration include lethargy, unconsciousness, very dry mouth, and a skin pinch that goes back very slowly.

 

Option D. Black: This is an incorrect option as the IMNCI color coding does not include black.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the IMNCI color coding system:

 

  • Green indicates no dehydration.
  • Yellow indicates some dehydration.
  • Pink indicates severe dehydration.

questions.text: The most common cancer found among the female population in India is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Breast cancer

 

In India, breast cancer is the most common cancer affecting the female population.

 

It ranks highest in terms of incidence, prevalence, and mortality among cancers in women.

 

Breast cancer has overtaken cervical cancer, which used to be the leading cause of cancer-related morbidity among Indian women. This shift reflects changes in lifestyle, reproductive patterns, and awareness.

 

Statistically, breast cancer is the leading cause of cancer deaths among Indian women, and its incidence continues to rise, making it a significant public health concern. Additionally, breast cancer is also the most common cancer when considering the total population (both male and female) combined.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral and lip cancer: While oral and lip cancers are common in India, particularly due to tobacco use, they are more prevalent in males and do not surpass breast cancer in females in terms of incidence.

 

Option B. Cervical cancer: Cervical cancer was previously the most common cancer among women in India. However, breast cancer has now overtaken it in terms of both incidence and mortality.

 

Option D. Lung cancer: Lung cancer, while common, is more prevalent in males. It is not the most common cancer among females in India.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Breast cancer is the most common cancer among the female population in India, leading in incidence, prevalence, and mortality rates. Followed by cervico-uterine cancer, ovarian cancer, lip and oral cavity cancer, and colorectal cancer, respectively.

questions.text: A 1-day old neonate presented with scaphoid abdomen, respiratory distress and mediastinal shift. All of the following can be done except? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bag and mask ventilation

 

Bag and mask ventilation can be challenging and less effective in the presence of a scaphoid abdomen and mediastinal shift. In such cases, positive pressure ventilation through an endotracheal tube or a ventilator may be more appropriate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. O2 by mask: This is a valid intervention. Providing oxygen by mask can be an initial step to improve oxygenation in a neonate with respiratory distress. The goal is to support oxygenation until more definitive measures can be taken.

 

Option B. Positive pressure ventilation by ventilator: This is a valid intervention. Positive pressure ventilation with a ventilator may be necessary in cases of severe respiratory distress or failure. It helps to provide adequate oxygenation and ventilation to the neonate.

 

Option C. ET intubation: This is a valid intervention. Endotracheal (ET) intubation may be indicated in cases where positive pressure ventilation is required or to secure the airway in the presence of respiratory distress.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the clinical signs of diaphragmatic hernia, such as a scaphoid abdomen, respiratory distress, and mediastinal shift. Understand the appropriate interventions, including oxygen administration, positive pressure ventilation, endotracheal intubation, and the limitations of bag and mask ventilation in specific clinical scenarios.

questions.text: A newborn presents with umbilical cord stump bleeding and a history of recurrent bleeding episodes. Laboratory results reveal normal PT, APTT, and platelet count, but a positive clot solubility test. What coagulation factor deficiency is most likely responsible for these symptoms? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Factor XIII

 

Factor XIII is essential for stabilizing fibrin clots by cross-linking fibrin monomers. A deficiency in Factor XIII leads to an unstable clot that dissolves easily, causing excessive bleeding despite normal routine coagulation tests such as PT (Prothrombin Time) and APTT (Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time).

 

  • Clinical presentation:
    • Umbilical stump bleeding is a hallmark feature of Factor XIII deficiency, occurring shortly after birth.
    •  Recurrent bleeding episodes, including delayed hemorrhage after trauma or surgery.
    •  Intracranial hemorrhage can occur even without trauma.
    • Poor wound healing due to defective clot stabilization.
  • Laboratory findings:
    • Normal PT, APTT, and platelet count, as Factor XIII operates in the final step of clot formation and does not affect routine coagulation screening tests.
    • Positive clot solubility test: Clots dissolve in 5M urea or acetic acid within 24 hours due to the lack of cross-linking fibrin.

 

Thus, the positive clot solubility test in this patient strongly indicates Factor XIII deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factor XII (Incorrect)

 

  • Hageman factor deficiency typically doesn't cause clinical bleeding
  • Would show prolonged aPTT on testing
  • Not associated with umbilical stump bleeding

 

Option B. Factor XI (Incorrect)

 

  • Would show prolonged aPTT
  • Not characteristically associated with umbilical cord bleeding
  • Clinical bleeding is usually mild and post-traumatic

 

Option C. Factor VIII (Incorrect)

 

  • Hemophilia A would show prolonged aPTT
  • While it causes bleeding, umbilical stump bleeding is not a characteristic presentation
  • Would not have a positive clot solubility test

 

Educational Objective:

 

Factor XIII deficiency presents with umbilical cord bleeding and shows normal PT, aPTT, and platelet count but positive clot solubility test due to unstable clot formation.

questions.text: Identify the chest x-ray finding shown below. (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lung collapse

 

A collapse can occur when part of the lung becomes airless and typically appears as an area of increased density. The X-ray provided shows a significant opacity along with volume loss, evidenced by the displacement of interlobar fissures and the mediastinum ipsilaterally, which is suggestive of collapse. This is often accompanied by compensatory hyperinflation in the unaffected areas.

 

The chest X-ray shows a significant abnormality in the lung field, suggestive of a lung collapse (atelectasis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Consolidation:  On an X-ray, consolidation typically appears as a uniform increase in pulmonary parenchymal opacity, which may obscure the lung markings and can sometimes involve an entire lobe. Air bronchograms (air-filled bronchi made visible by the opaque alveoli around them) may be visible. There is no mediastinal shift which is typically associated.

 

Option B. Effusion: On an X-ray, this typically shows as a blunting of the costophrenic angles, with fluid layering dependently and possibly causing a meniscus sign along the chest wall. With contralateral mediastinal shift

 

Option D. Intrathoracic Mass Lesion: A mass would typically appear as a well-defined area of increased density, which might push against or compress adjacent structures. The image does not clearly show such characteristics, as the opacity seems too extensive and involves a loss of volume rather than a discrete mass pushing on surrounding tissues.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The opacity and associated signs of volume loss indicate that part of the lung has collapsed, likely due to an obstruction or compression of the airways.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with diarrhea and weight loss. On examination, the height and weight are lesser than expected. Laboratory investigations were positive for class II HLA-DQ2. Which of the following will you advise the child? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gluten-free diet

 

The positive HLA-DQ2 and the presentation of diarrhea and weight loss in a child suggest the possibility of celiac disease. Therefore, the child should be advised to follow a gluten-free diet.

 

Celiac disease is a condition characterized by an abnormal immune response to gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye. This immune response leads to damage to the small intestine and malabsorption of nutrients, which can result in diarrhea, weight loss, and other symptoms.

 

HLA-DQ2 is a genetic marker that is present in over 90% of individuals with celiac disease. Therefore, a positive test for HLA-DQ2 can suggest the possibility of celiac disease, although a definitive diagnosis requires further testing, such as serologic testing and intestinal biopsy.

 

The pathogenesis of celiac disease involves an inflammatory response to gluten and gliadin, a gluten-derived peptide. In the small intestine, gliadin is deamidated by an intestinal enzyme called tissue transglutaminase (tTG), resulting in a more immunogenic form of the protein that is presented to helper T cells. This leads to mucosal inflammation, tissue damage, and other symptoms.

 

Children with celiac disease typically present with diarrhea, weight loss, and growth failure. Other symptoms may include malabsorption, bloating, irregular bowel habits, iron deficiency anemia, osteoporosis, ataxia, and abnormal liver enzymes. Screening for celiac disease is performed by testing for serum antibodies, including tissue transglutaminase IgA, anti-endomysial, and deaminated anti-gliadin antibodies. The diagnosis is confirmed in patients with positive antibodies by biopsy of the second part of the duodenum or proximal jejunum. Microscopic examination of the biopsy sample reveals intraepithelial CD8+ lymphocytes, villous atrophy, and crypt hyperplasia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fat-free diet: This is not relevant to the management of celiac disease. Fat intake is not directly related to the immune response triggered by gluten.

 

Option B. Lactose-free diet: While some individuals with celiac disease may temporarily develop lactose intolerance due to mucosal damage, a lactose-free diet is not the primary treatment.

 

Option C. Low carbohydrate diet: This diet is not related to the management of celiac disease. The primary issue is the immune response to gluten, not carbohydrate intake.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Children with celiac disease should follow a gluten-free diet to manage symptoms and prevent further intestinal damage.

questions.text: Identify the image: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bier’s block

 

The image depicts the setup for a Bier’s block, also known as intravenous regional anesthesia (IVRA).

 

This technique is commonly used for short surgical procedures on the extremities, such as the hands or forearms.

 

The process involves placing a double cuff tourniquet on the limb to occlude blood flow, then injecting a local anesthetic (such as lidocaine) into a vein in the isolated limb.

 

The tourniquet prevents the anesthetic from circulating out of the limb, thus providing anesthesia to the area. Bier's block is a fast and effective method for producing anesthesia in a limb without the need for general anesthesia or nerve blocks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radial nerve block: A radial nerve block involves injecting anesthetic near the radial nerve . It does not involve a tourniquet or intravenous injection of local anesthetic as depicted in the image.

 

Option B. Axillary block: An axillary block is a type of brachial plexus block where anesthetic is injected near the axillary artery to block the nerves supplying the upper limb.

 

Option D. Wrist block: A wrist block involves injecting local anesthetic near the nerves at the wrist to provide anesthesia to the hand. It is different from Bier's block and does not involve a tourniquet or intravenous injection as shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bier’s block, or intravenous regional anesthesia (IVRA), is used for anesthetizing a limb by injecting local anesthetic into a vein while using a tourniquet to confine the anesthetic to the limb.

questions.text: The following are the phases of:(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Demographic process

 

Explanation:

 

Demography is the scientific study of human populations, and demographic processes are the key factors that influence population dynamics. The five main demographic processes mentioned in the image are:

 

  1. Fertility: Related to childbirth and reproduction
  2. Mortality: Related to deaths and life expectancy
  3. Marriage: Formation and dissolution of marital unions
  4. Migration: Physical or geographical movement of people from one place to another
  5. Social mobility: Movement of individuals across social classes or socio-economic status

 

These processes collectively determine the size, structure, and distribution of populations over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Demographic dividend: This refers to the economic growth potential resulting from a population's changing age structure, typically when the working-age population is larger than the non-working-age population. It is not directly related to the five processes listed.

 

Option C. Demographic cycle: Also known as the demographic transition model, this describes the stages a population goes through as it transitions from high birth and death rates to low birth and death rates. While related to demographic processes, the stages of the demographic cycle are not the same as the processes listed.

 

Option D. Human Development Index (HDI): This is a composite statistic developed by the United Nations to measure and rank countries' levels of social and economic development. It takes into account life expectancy, education, and per capita income. HDI is not directly related to the five demographic processes mentioned.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fertility, mortality, marriage, migration, and social mobility are the five main demographic processes that influence population dynamics and are studied in the field of demography.

questions.text: Following an accident, a patient presented with an inability to flex the MCP joint and extend the IP joint of his hand. Which nerve is damaged here? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ulnar nerve

 

The patient’s symptoms of being unable to flex the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and extend the interphalangeal (IP) joints suggest a problem with the lumbrical muscles. The lumbricals are responsible for these movements. Specifically, the third and fourth lumbrical muscles, which flex the MCP joints and extend the IP joints of the ring and little fingers, are innervated by the ulnar nerve. Damage to the ulnar nerve can result in a condition known as "claw hand," where these functions are compromised, leading to the inability to perform the described movements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radial nerve: The radial nerve primarily controls the extension of the wrist and fingers, but not the flexion of the MCP joints or extension of the IP joints. Hence, it is not involved in this condition.

 

Option B. Anterior interosseous nerve: This is a branch of the median nerve, primarily responsible for the motor function of some of the deep muscles in the forearm but does not innervate the lumbricals. Therefore, it is not responsible for the symptoms described.

 

Option D. Musculocutaneous nerve: This nerve innervates the muscles in the anterior compartment of the arm, responsible for elbow flexion, but it does not play a role in the movement of the fingers or hand. Therefore, it is not the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ulnar nerve is responsible for innervating the third and fourth lumbricals, which are essential for flexing the MCP joints and extending the IP joints. Damage to this nerve can lead to the characteristic "claw hand" deformity.

questions.text: A young male had a road traffic accident and was brought to emergency with stable vitals. Which wound is not expected:(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Chop wound

 

In the context of a road traffic accident, different types of wounds can be expected depending on the nature of the injury.

 

Chop Wound typically caused by a heavy, sharp tool like an axe or a machete. These are not typically seen in road traffic accidents unless there is a very specific scenario involving such an implement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple Bruises: These are common in road traffic accidents due to blunt force trauma where the body strikes objects like the steering wheel, dashboard, or gets jostled against seat belts.

 

Option C. Graze Abrasion: Often occurs when the skin slides across a rough surface, such as in motorcycle accidents when the rider is dragged along the pavement.

 

Option D. Laceration: These are irregular tears in the skin commonly caused by blunt trauma, which is typical in road traffic accidents when sharp or rough metal edges and glass are involved.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chop wounds are unusual in road traffic accidents .

choices.text: Laser ablation can be used for treatment

questions.text: A patient presents to the outpatient department (OPD) with dilated, tortuous veins in the leg. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Laser ablation can be used for treatment

 

Explanation:

 

Endovenous laser ablation (EVLA) is an effective minimally invasive treatment for varicose veins

 

  • EVLA works by using laser energy to cause thermal damage to vein wall
  • It has high success rate and faster recovery compared to traditional surgery
  • It is currently the treatment of choice for great saphenous vein varicosities
  • Done under local tumescent anesthesia as daycare procedure

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clinical stage is C6: Incorrect as C6 indicates active venous ulcer. This patient only shows varicose veins which is C2 in CEAP classification (C2S if symptomatic, C2A if asymptomatic)

 

Option C. Sclerotherapy is the first-line treatment: Incorrect as sclerotherapy is primarily used for small reticular veins and telangiectasias, not for large varicose veins

 

Option D. Compression stockings are curative: Incorrect as compression stockings only provide symptomatic relief and don't cure varicose veins. They help manage symptoms but disease continues to progress

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endovenous Laser Ablation (EVLA) is an effective, first-line treatment for symptomatic varicose veins. Compression stockings provide symptom relief but are not curative.

questions.text: A chronic smoker was on nicotine replacement therapy and clonidine tablets for smoking de-addiction. He stopped taking clonidine tablets and now presents with a headache. What is the reason behind this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rebound hypertension

 

Clonidine is an alpha-2 agonist and a centrally acting antihypertensive agent. Used in HTN. Stimulates presynaptic α-receptor in the vasomotor centre in the brainstem, suppressing the release of norepinephrine and other sympathomimetics.

 

Clonidine sudden stoppage causes Rebound HTN and sympathetic overactivity.

 

Treatment of clonidine withdrawal is Phentolamine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Postural Hypotension

 

  • Description: A condition where blood pressure drops significantly upon standing up.
  • Relevance: Clonidine can cause postural hypotension, but sudden discontinuation leads to rebound hypertension, not postural hypotension.

 

Option B. Receptor Upregulation

 

  • Description: An increase in the number of receptors on the cell surface.
  • Relevance: This concept is more related to long-term exposure to antagonists, not the sudden withdrawal of an agonist like clonidine.

 

Option D. Receptor Hypersensitivity

 

  • Description: Increased sensitivity of receptors to a stimulus.
  • Relevance: While receptor hypersensitivity can occur, it is not the primary mechanism behind the headache and rebound hypertension seen with sudden clonidine withdrawal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rebound hypertension is a critical condition that can occur when clonidine, an alpha-2 agonist, is suddenly discontinued. This results in a rapid increase in sympathetic activity, leading to symptoms such as headache due to a sudden spike in blood pressure.
